revision.text:
{{Redirect|Crown Prince Wilhelm|ships of this name|Kronprinz Wilhelm (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|Wilhelm of Prussia}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{stack|{{Infobox royalty |name = Wilhelm |title = German Crown Prince
Crown Prince of Prussia |image = William, German Crown Prince.jpg |image_size = 238px |caption = The German Crown Prince. |succession = [[House of Hohenzollern#Hohenzollerns since 1918 abdication|Head of the House of Hohenzollern]] |reign = 4 June 1941 – 20 July 1951 |reign-type = Period |predecessor = [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]] |successor = [[Louis Ferdinand, Prince of Prussia|Prince Louis Ferdinand]] |house = [[House of Hohenzollern|Hohenzollern]] |spouse = {{Marriage|[[Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]]|6 June 1905|20 July 1951}} |issue = [[Prince Wilhelm of Prussia (1906–1940)|Prince Wilhelm]]
[[Louis Ferdinand, Prince of Prussia|Prince Louis Ferdinand]]
[[Prince Hubertus of Prussia|Prince Hubertus]]
[[Prince Frederick of Prussia (1911–1966)|Prince Friedrich]]
Princess Alexandrine
Princess Cecilie, Mrs. Harris |birth_date = {{Birth date|1882|5|6|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Marmorpalais]], [[Potsdam]], Germany |death_date = {{Death date and age|1951|7|20|1882|5|6|df=y}} |death_place = [[Hechingen]], [[Württemberg-Hohenzollern]], Germany |burial_date = 26 July 1951 |place of burial = [[Hohenzollern Castle]], [[Wurttemberg-Hohenzollern]], Germany |father = [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor]] |mother = [[Augusta Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein]]}} {{House of Hohenzollern (Prussia)|william2}}}} '''German Crown Prince Wilhelm''' ({{lang-de|Kronprinz Wilhelm von Preußen}}; {{nowrap|6 May 1882 –}} {{nowrap|20 July 1951)}}, full name '''Friedrich Wilhelm Victor August Ernst''', was the last [[Crown Prince]] of the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] and the [[German Empire]]. He was born on 6 May 1882 in the [[Marmorpalais]] in [[Potsdam]], the eldest child of the future German Emperor [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]] and his wife Empress [[Augusta Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein|Augusta Victoria]]. After the death of his grandfather Emperor [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Frederick III]], Wilhelm became Crown Prince of Germany at the age of six, retaining that title for more than 30 years until the fall of the empire on 5 November 1918. During [[World War I]], he commanded the [[5th Army (German Empire)|5th Army]] from 1914 to 1916 and was commander of [[Army Group German Crown Prince]] for the remainder of the war. Crown Prince Wilhelm became [[House of Hohenzollern#Hohenzollerns since 1918 abdication|Head of the House of Hohenzollern]] on 4 June 1941 following the death of his father and held the position until his own death on 20 July 1951. ==Early life== [[File:Germany Before the First World War 1890 - 1914 HU68364.jpg|thumbnail|left|Crown Prince Wilhelm, aged 19, wearing civilian clothing]] Wilhelm was born on 6 May 1882 in the [[Marmorpalais]] of [[Potsdam]] in the [[Province of Brandenburg]]. He was the eldest son of [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]], the last German Emperor (1859–1941) and his first wife, Princess [[Augusta Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein]] (1858–1921). When he was born, his great-grandfather, [[Kaiser Wilhelm I]], was the reigning emperor and his grandfather, [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Crown Prince Frederick]], [[Frederick III, German Emperor| ]]was heir to the throne, making Wilhelm third in line to the throne. He was the eldest of the Kaiser's seven children, and his birth sparked an argument between his parents and [[Victoria, Princess Royal|grandmother]]. Before Wilhelm was born, his grandmother had expected to be asked to help find a nurse, but since her son did everything he could to snub her, the future Wilhelm II asked his aunt [[Princess Helena of the United Kingdom|Helena]] to help. His mother was hurt and his [[Queen Victoria|grandmother]] furious.Queen Victoria's Family, A Century of Photographs, [[Charlotte Zeepvat]] When his great-grandfather and grandfather both died in 1888, six-year-old Wilhelm became the heir-apparent to the German and Prussian thrones. Wilhelm was a supporter of [[association football]], then a relatively new sport in the country, donating a cup to the [[German Football Association]] in 1908 and thereby initiating the ''[[Länderpokal|Kronprinzenpokal (now Länderpokal)]]'', the oldest cup competition in German football.[http://einestages.spiegel.de/static/topicalbumbackground/4242/kick_it_like_kronprinz.html "Kick it like Kronprinz"] {{de icon}} [[Der Spiegel|Spiegel]] Online. Retrieved 11 June 2009 The German club [[BFC Preussen]] was also originally named BFC Friedrich Wilhelm in his honour. ==Relations with family== {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2015}} Kaiser Wilhelm II regarded his eldest son with contempt, mainly because of his many affairs with women. In 1901, during a visit to [[Blenheim Palace]] in England, the Crown Prince took a strong liking to [[Gladys Deacon]] and gave her a ring that she had to return, at his father's insistence. Crown Prince Wilhelm, on the other hand, became noted for his public criticism of the politics of his father. In response, his father found Wilhelm a wife, [[Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]], and ordered him to stay in [[Danzig]], away from the Imperial court. After initial interest in his wife, the Prince returned to his previous interest in other women.{{Citation needed|date = October 2012}} During his stay in [[Danzig]] he used to regularly play tennis in [[Sopot]]. That afforded him a chance to meet many beautiful women, many of them coming from [[Warsaw]] to stay at the [[spa]].{{Citation needed|date = October 2012}} In 1914, the Kaiser ordered the construction of Schloss [[Cecilienhof]] in Potsdam for Prince Wilhelm and his family. Completed in 1917, it became the main residence for the Crown Prince for a time. ==World War I== Wilhelm had been active in pushing German expansion, and sought a leading role on the outbreak of war. Despite being only thirty-two and having never commanded a unit larger than a regiment, the German Crown Prince was named commander of the [[5th Army (German Empire)|5th Army]] in August 1914, shortly after the outbreak of [[World War I]]. However, under the well-established Prussian/[[German General Staff]] model then in use, inexperienced nobles who were afforded commands of large army formations were always provided with (and expected to defer to the advice of) experienced Chiefs of Staff to assist them in their duties. As Emperor, Wilhelm's father instructed the Crown Prince to defer to the advice of his experienced Chief of Staff [[Konstantin Schmidt von Knobelsdorf]].Chief of Staff: Napoleonic wars to World War I, David Zabecki In October 1914 Wilhelm gave his first interview to a foreign correspondent and the first statement to the press made by a German noble since the outbreak of war.[[#AE|Elter page 74]][[#KW|Wiegand page 3]] He blandly denied promoting military solutions to diplomatic problems, and said this in English: {{quote|"Undoubtedly this is the most stupid, senseless and unnecessary war of modern times. It is a war not wanted by Germany, I can assure you, but it was forced on us, and the fact that we were so effectually prepared to defend ourselves is now being used as an argument to convince the world that we desired conflict."|Crown Prince Wilhelm|''Wiegand''}} From August 1915 onwards, Wilhelm was given the additional role as commander of [[Army Group German Crown Prince]]. In 1916 his troops began the [[Battle of Verdun|Verdun Offensive]], a year long effort to destroy the French armies that would end in failure. Wilhelm relinquished command of the 5th Army in November of that year, but remained commander of Army Group German Crown Prince for the rest of the war. ==1918–34== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-14437, Tag von Potsdam, Adolf Hitler, Kronprinz Wilhelm.jpg|thumb|left|Meeting Adolf Hitler in 1933]] After the outbreak of the [[German Revolution]] in 1918, both Emperor Wilhelm II and the Crown Prince signed the document of abdication. On 13 November, the former Crown Prince went into exile and was interned on the island of [[Wieringen]] (now part of the mainland), near [[Den Helder]] in the [[Netherlands]]. In the fall of 1921, [[Gustav Stresemann]] visited Wilhelm and the Crown Prince voiced his interest in returning to [[Weimar Republic|Germany]], even as a private citizen. After Stresemann became chancellor in August 1923, Wilhelm was allowed to return after giving assurances that he would no longer engage in politics. He chose 9 November 1923 for this, which infuriated his father, who had not been informed about the plans of his son and who felt [[November 9 in German history|the historic date]] to be inappropriate.{{cite book|last1=Müller|first1=Heike|last2=Berndt|first2=Harald|title=Schloss Cecilienhof und die Konferenz von Potsdam 1945 (German)|publisher=Stiftung Preussische Schlösser und Gärten|year=2006|isbn=3-910068-16-2| page=}}{{rp|11–12}} In June 1926, a [[German referendum, 1926|referendum on expropriating the former ruling Princes of Germany without compensation]] failed and as a consequence, the financial situation of the Hohenzollern family improved considerably. A settlement between the state and the family made Cecilienhof property of the state but granted a right of residence to Wilhelm and Cecilie. This was limited in duration to three generations.{{rp|9–12}} The family also kept the ownership of [[Monbijou Palace]] in Berlin, [[Oleśnica|Oels]] Castle in Silesia and [[Rheinsberg Palace]] until 1945.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Wilhelm broke the promise he had made to Stresemann to stay out of politics. [[Adolf Hitler]] visited Wilhelm at Cecilienhof three times, in 1926, in 1933 (on the "Day of Potsdam") and in 1935. Wilhelm joined the ''[[Stahlhelm, Bund der Frontsoldaten|Stahlhelm]]'' which merged in 1931 into the [[Harzburg Front]], a right-wing organisation of those opposed to the democratic republic.{{rp|13}} The former Crown Prince was reportedly interested in the idea of running for ''[[Reichspräsident]]'' as the right-wing candidate against [[Paul von Hindenburg]] in 1932, until his father forbade him from acting on the idea. After his plans to become president had been blocked by his father, Wilhelm supported the rise to power of Hitler.{{rp|13}} {{Clear}} ==1934–51== [[File:La cour intérieure du château de Cecilienhof (Potsdam) (2731361224).jpg|thumb|[[Cecilienhof]]]] [[File:3273viki Zamek w Oleśnicy. Foto Barbara Maliszewska.jpg|thumb|[[Oleśnica|Oels]] Castle]] After the murder of his friend [[Kurt von Schleicher]], the former Chancellor, in the [[Night of the Long Knives]] (1934), he withdrew from all political activities. When Wilhelm realized that Hitler had no intention of restoring the monarchy, their relationship cooled. Upon his father's death in 1941, Wilhelm succeeded him as head of the [[House of Hohenzollern]], the former German imperial dynasty. He was approached by those in the military and the diplomatic service who wanted to replace Hitler, but Wilhelm turned them down. After the [[20 July Plot|assassination attempt on 20 July 1944]], Hitler nevertheless had Wilhelm placed under supervision by the [[Gestapo]] and had his home at Cecilienhof watched.{{rp|11–15}} In January 1945, Wilhelm left Potsdam for [[Oberstdorf]] for a treatment of his gall and liver problems. His wife Cecilie fled in early February 1945 as the [[Red Army]] drew closer to Berlin, but they had been estranged for a long time. At the end of the war, Wilhelm's home, Cecilienhof, was seized by the Soviets.{{rp|15–16}} The palace was subsequently used by the Allied Powers as the venue for the [[Potsdam Conference]].{{rp|16}} At the end of the war, Wilhelm was captured by French Moroccan troops in Baad, Austria and was interned as a (World War I) war criminal. Transferred to [[Hechingen]], Germany, he lived for a short time in [[Hohenzollern Castle]] under house arrest before moving to a small five-room house at Fürstenstraße 16 in Hechingen where he died on 20 July 1951, of a heart attack. Three days later, his opponent in the [[Battle of Verdun]], Marshal [[Philippe Pétain]], died in prison in France.The Life Of Crown Prince William by Klaus Jonas, 1961 pp. 214-30. Wilhelm and his wife are buried at Hohenzollern Castle.{{cite web|url=http://www.preussen.de/de/geschichte/kronprinz_wilhelm.html|title=Preussen.de - Kronprinz Wilhelm|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.preussen.de/de/heute/aktuell/archiv/50._todestag_der_kronprinzessin_cecilie.html|title=Preussen.de - 50. Todestag der Kronprinzessin Cecilie|publisher=}} ==Family and children== [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-01280, Kaiser Wilhelm II. mit Sohn und Enkel.jpg|thumb|With his father and his son, Prince Wilhelm, in 1927]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-2003-1014-505, Potsdam, Kronprinzessin Cecilie mit ihren Töchtern.jpg|thumb|Wilhelm's wife, Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, and daughters, Princess Alexandrine (left) and Princess Cecilie (right), pictured in 1934]] Wilhelm married [[Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] (20 September 1886 – 6 May 1954) in [[Berlin]] on 6 June 1905. After their marriage, the couple lived at the [[Kronprinzenpalais|Crown Prince's Palace in Berlin]] in the winter and at the Marmorpalais in Potsdam. Cecilie was the daughter of Grand Duke [[Frederick Francis III, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Frederick Francis III]] of [[Grand Duchy of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] (1851–1897) and his wife, [[Grand Duchess Anastasia Mikhailovna of Russia]] (1860–1922). Their eldest son, Prince Wilhelm of Prussia, was killed fighting for the [[German Army (Wehrmacht)|German Army]] in [[Battle of France|France in 1940]]. However, during the early stages of his marriage the crown prince had a brief affair with the American opera singer [[Geraldine Farrar]], and he later had a relationship with the dancer [[Mata Hari]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} Their children and male-line grandchildren are: *[[Prince Wilhelm of Prussia (1906–1940)|Prince Wilhelm of Prussia]] (1906–1940), who renounced his succession right. He married [[Dorothea von Salviati]] and had issue: **[[Princess Felicitas of Prussia]] (1934–2009) **Princess Christa of Prussia (born 1936) *[[Louis Ferdinand, Prince of Prussia]] (1907–1994); married [[Grand Duchess Kira Kirillovna of Russia]] and had issue: **Prince Friedrich Wilhelm of Prussia (1939–2015) **Prince Michael of Prussia (1940–2014) **[[Princess Marie Cécile of Prussia]] (born 1942) **[[Princess Kira of Prussia]] (1943–2004) **[[Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia (1944–1977)|Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia]] (1944–1977) **[[Prince Christian-Sigismund of Prussia]] (born 1946) **Princess Xenia of Prussia (1949–1992) *[[Prince Hubertus of Prussia]] (1909–1950); married Baroness Maria von Humboldt-Dachroeden and [[Princess Magdalena Reuss of Köstritz]], had issue: **Princess Anastasia of Prussia (born 1944) **Princess Marie-Christine of Prussia (1947–1966) *[[Prince Frederick of Prussia (1911–1966)|Prince Frederick of Prussia]] (1911–1966); married [[Lady Brigid Guinness]] and had issue: **Prince Frederick Nicholas of Prussia (born 1946) **Prince Andrew of Prussia (born 1947) **Princess Victoria of Prussia (born 1952) **Prince Rupert of Prussia (born 1955) **[[Princess Antonia, Duchess of Wellington|Princess Antonia of Prussia]] (born 1955) *Princess Alexandrine Irene of Prussia (1915–1980), called "Adini", had [[Down syndrome]]. *Princess Cecilie Viktoria Anastasia Zita Thyra Adelheid of Prussia (1917–1975) she married [[Clyde Kenneth Harris]] on 21 June 1949: **Kira Alexandrine Brigid Cecilie Ingrid Harris (20 October 1954) she married John Mitchell Johnson, son of Joseph Edward Johnson and Blanche Dabney, on 22 May 1982. They have one son: ***Philip Louis Johnson (18 October 1985) Their surviving descendants are in the [[line of succession to the British throne]]. ==Titles, styles, honours and arms== ===Titles and styles=== *''' 6 May 1882 – 15 June 1888''': ''His Royal Highness'' Prince Wilhelm of Prussia *''' 15 June 1888 – 10 August 1919''': ''His Imperial and Royal Highness'' The German Crown Prince, Crown Prince of Prussia *''' 11 August 1919 – 20 July 1951''': ''Mr'' Wilhelm Kronprinz von Preußen **In pretence:''' 11 August 1919 – 4 June 1941:''' ''His Imperial and Royal Highness'' The German Crown Prince, Crown Prince of Prussia **In pretence: '''4 June 1941 – 20 July 1951:''' ''His Imperial & Royal Majesty'' The German Emperor, King of Prussia (Title held in pretence as the German monarchy has been abolished.) ==Ancestry== {{Ahnentafel top|width=100%}} {{Ahnentafel-compact5 |style=font-size: 90%; line-height: 110%; |border=1 |boxstyle=padding-top: 0; padding-bottom: 0; |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. [[Princess Victoria of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld]] (= 23) }} {{Ahnentafel bottom}} ==Decorations and awards== ;German honours * Knight of the [[Order of the Black Eagle]] * Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Red Eagle]] * [[Pour le Mérite]] * Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Crown (Prussia)]] * {{Flag|Kingdom of Bavaria}}: Grand Cross of the [[Military Order of Max Joseph]] * {{Flag|Kingdom of Saxony}}: Grand Cross of the [[Military Order of St. Henry]] * {{Flag|Mecklenburg-Schwerin}}: [[Military Merit Cross (Mecklenburg-Schwerin)|Military Merit Cross]], 1st class ;Foreign honors * {{Flag|Austria-Hungary}}: Knight of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] (Austrian branch) * {{Flag|Spain}}: Knight of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] (Spanish branch) - ''January 1900'' - the insignia was the same as those which were worn by the [[Wilhelm I|Emperor Wilhelm I]]{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Court Circular|day_of_week=Thursday |date=11 January 1900|page_number=7 |issue=36036| }} * {{Flag|United Kingdom}}: Knight of the [[Order of the Garter]] - expelled in 1915 * {{Flag|Norway}}: Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of St. Olav]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{citation |author=Andreas Elter |title=Die andere Front: Pressepolitik in den USKriegen des 20. Jahrhunderts |url=http://deposit.ddb.de/cgi-bin/dokserv?idn=968575013&dok_var=d1&dok_ext=pdf&filename=968575013.pdf |date=April 2003 |language=German |format=PDF |location=Cologne |accessdate=5 April 2009|ref=AE}} * {{citation |author=Karl Henry von Wiegand |authorlink=Karl von Wiegand |title=Current misconceptions about the war |url=https://archive.org/details/currentmisconcep00vonw |publisher=The Fatherland corporation, inc. |year=1915 |location=1123 Broadway, New York |accessdate=5 April 2009 |quote=Copyright 1914, United Press ... 20 November|ref=KW}} ==External links== {{Commons category|William, German Crown Prince}} *[https://archive.org/details/memoirsofcrownpr00wilhuoft ''The memoirs of the Crown Prince of Germany ''] *[https://archive.org/details/lifeofcrownprinc007251mbp ''The Life of Crown Prince Wilhelm''] *{{Cite EB1922|wstitle=William |short=x}} {{S-start}} {{S-hou|[[House of Hohenzollern]]|6 May|1882|20 July|1951}} {{S-pre|}} {{S-break}} {{S-bef|before=[[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]]|as=[[List of German monarchs|German Emperor]]
and [[List of rulers of Prussia|King of Prussia]]}} {{S-tul|title=[[List of German monarchs|German Emperor]]

(''VII. Armee-Inspektion'') | after=[[General of the Infantry (Germany)|General der Infanterie]] [[Ewald von Lochow]] | years=2 August 1914-30 November 1916}} {{Succession box| title=Commander, [[Army Group German Crown Prince]]| before=New Creation | after=[[Karl von Einem]] | years=1 August 1915 - 10 November 1918}} {{S-end}} {{Pretenders to the German and Prussian thrones since 1918}} {{Prussian princes}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:People from Potsdam]] [[Category:People from the Province of Brandenburg]] [[Category:Prussian princes]] [[Category:House of Hohenzollern]] [[Category:Crown Princes of Prussia]] [[Category:Heirs apparent who never acceded]] [[Category:Pretenders to the German throne]] [[Category:Generals of Infantry (Prussia)]] [[Category:German military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Recipients of the Pour le Mérite (military class)]] [[Category:Grand Crosses of the Military Order of Max Joseph]] [[Category:Knights of the Golden Fleece]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Black Eagle]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of St. Andrew]] [[Category:Grand Crosses of the Order of the Red Eagle]] [[Category:Grand Crosses of the Military Order of St. Henry]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Merit Cross (Mecklenburg-Schwerin), 1st class]] [[Category:National Socialist Motor Corps members]] [[Category:German monarchists]]
